lines.text:
[stands up in class to present a report]
The Six Senses.
Oh, the subject I gave you was the five senses.
Well, I chose for my subject six senses.

[baffled and confused]
Well, go on, Patricia. Go on.
To see, to hear, to taste, to smell, to feel... to be.
You don't become a nun to run away from life, Patsy. It's not because you've lost something. It's because you've found something.
I can see you don't know what it means to be up to your neck in nuns.
If we don't fail sometimes, our successes won't mean anything. You must have courage. Don't give up.
And if you ever need anything, no matter what it is or wherever you happen to be...
Yes, I know. I just dial O for O'Malley.
To put it in my own words, "To be or not to be, that is the question."
There's another sense, you know, Sister.
Oh, don't tell me.
Yes, sense enough to know when to leave.

[having just seen the first-graders' Christmas play]
Oh, their simplicity is beautiful. I wouldn't change a word of it.
Oh, but THEY will.
Does she know about this.

Oh, not yet. It's very important that she doesn't know it. She has a wonderful vitality, a natural optimism, and that's the best medicine anyone can have. If that spirit is dampened, it would... it would have a depressing effect and delay her recovery.
She'll have to know about it. We... we can't just send her away without...
Don't you people, uh, more or less, uh, go where you're told without question?

[Sister Mary Benedict calls a boy named Luther to recite material]
Luther? How'd he get in here?
We never knew.
Did anyone ever tell you that you have a dishonest face? For a priest, I mean.
This is Mary and I'm Joseph and we're going to Bethlehem to see if we can have someplace... find someplace to stay, and that's all you have to know, really.
There's one thing I do know - something is troubling you.
No. No, I just want to be a nun.
